awd_titl_txt: Entanglement Physics of Quantum f-electron Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education in condensed matter physics, in the subfield of f-electron physics and quantum matter.

The behavior of matter on atomic scales is governed by quantum mechanics, which describes the motion of particles as a wave, evolving according to the Schrodinger wave equation. While the application of this equation to isolated electrons is fully understood, the corresponding many-body version of this equation that governs the collective quantum behavior of electrons inside matter is far too complex to be solved in detail. The astronomical scale of this complexity may be grasped by noting that the number of electrons in a pound of iron is larger than the number of stars in the known universe.

One of the strange manifestations of quantum mechanics is a phenomenon known as entanglement, whereby remote electrons in a material intimately correlate their motion. The unexpected collective behavior of electrons that results from this entanglement has the capacity to endow quantum matter with emergent properties, such as magnetism, superconductivity, or superfluidity, and many more that are presumably not yet discovered. The quest to understand and manipulate these emergent properties, and to relate them to the underlying quantum mechanics is a key goal of modern condensed matter physics.

The award supports research in the area of f-electron materials, a unique class of metals that can be fine-tuned to the brink of magnetism where they develop a special quantum state called a "Quantum Critical Point". Quantum critical points can be thought of as a kind of electronic stem cell - a state of matter that can easily transform itself into a broad class of novel quantum phases, such as unconventional superconductors. By developing a new mathematical description of these quantum critical points and the phases they can transform into, the PI aims to gain a new understanding of the physics of quantum materials.

Graduate students and postdocs will be involved in an essential way in the research, and will be mentored and trained in a broad range of theoretical techniques. The PI also plans to write a popular book introducing the frontier of quantum condensed matter physics to non-experts.

 
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education in condensed matter physics, in the subfield of f-electron physics.  The research has three main subheadings: 

1) New approach to quantum criticality: Using a new Schwinger boson method, and working in conjunction with experimentalists, the research team will develop a theory of ferromagnetic quantum criticality in heavy-electron materials. This work will be extended to antiferromagnets and will be used to compute the generalized phase diagram of heavy fermions. The research team will develop a theory for the co-existence of magnetism and the Kondo effect. By extending early work of Larkin and Pikin, the research will develop a theory for the quantum annealing of finite-temperature first-order phase transitions into quantum critical points at absolute zero. 

2) Analytic-computational approach to entanglement & novel order in rare-earth materials: Working with theorists at the Flatiron Institute, New York, the research team will apply Matrix Product State approaches to simple one- and two-dimensional Kondo lattices, focusing on the low-entanglement case of the Kondo insulator, using these methods to establish and explore the composite nature of heavy fermions.

3) A new approach to Raman and Photoemission phenomenology: Generalizing the theory of optical lattices to crystal fields, the research will develop a theory of the Raman interaction of light with crystal-field levels in f-electron materials. A new criterion for measuring the degree of localization of f-electrons using angle-resolved and core-level x-ray photoemission will be developed.

Graduate students and postdocs will be involved in an essential way in the research, and will be mentored and trained in a broad range of theoretical techniques. The PI also plans to write a popular book introducing the frontier of quantum condensed matter physics to non-experts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

One of the remarkable consequences of quantum mechanics, is the abilty of electrons to develop entangled states, in which they are simultaneousely in two different configurations, as exemplified by "Schrodinger's Cat"  being simultaneously dead and alive. The focus of this research is on quantum materials, insulators or metals in which the entanglement between electrons gives rise to newr "emergent" properties that not only teach us about quantum physics, but offer the prospect of new technologies, such as the use of high temperature superconducting magnets in compact tokamak fusion reactors and high resolution magnetic resonance imaging. 

Quantum matter shows a predelicition to form such high entangled states  when the material  is close to instability into a new phase. Such instabilities, called "Quantum Phase transitions" are  fruitful places to seek now forms of emergent matter.  We are particularly interested in a particular variety of such transitions, known as a quantum critical point, in which the development of intense slow quantum fluctuations transform the property of metals into "strange metals" with properties that are only partially understood, that are a central focus of the research in this grant. 

The research funded by this NSF grant involves theory experimental collaborations to understand quantum materials, particularly in the vicinity of quantum critical points.  Theory-experiment collaborations tend to drive a rapid convection of discovery and new theory. 

One area of research activity concerns the  metallic ferromagnet, formula CeRh6Ge4, which under pressure  becomes a strange metal, with a resistivity that is linear in temperature. (Fig. 1)  Ferromagnets, in which electrons align their spins in a single direction usually lack the entanglement to develop strange metallic behavior.  We were able to show that the entanglement derives from the large easy plane anisotropy, and developed a theoretical model that accounts for the unusual quantum critcality. 

Another area of research concerns  polar metals, which contain a low density of electrons moving through a lattice at the brink of instability into a ferroelectric - a lattice with a net electrical polarization.  Experiments on the polar material strontium titanate (formula SrTiO3) have shown that is prone to develop superconductivity close to the polar instability.   Mysteriously, the intense polar fluctuations in these systems do not produce charge fluctuations, and thus decouple from the charged electrons in the metal.  Inspired by the analogy with Dark Matter, which only interacts with our world via gravity, or energy fluctuations, we developed a theory of superconductivity driven by the coupling of electrons to the intense energy fluctuations at a polar critical point (Fig. 2).  Our theory predicts that in future experiments, thin films of polar metal will exhibit an even stronger superconducting response to quantum criticality.

One of our key collaborations is with a Japanese group at the University of Tokyo, studying the strange metal Ytterbium Aluminum Boron (YbAlB4) called "y-ball". There is very little known about the charge dynamics in strange metals (Fig 3.)  Using a new method as "Synchrotron Mossbauer Spectroscopy" we carried out the first study of charge fluctuations in a strange metal. Mossbauer spectroscopysubtle changes in the frequency of radiation from the atomic nucleus to probe the number of electrons at the atom. Usually, this requires radioactive isotopes, but by using intense X-rays from a synchrotron, it is now possible to carry out such experiments using non-radioactive samples. Measurements revealed that when YbAlB4 is cooled into the strange metal, the charge fluctuations on the Ytterbium atoms slow down dramatically  to produce a two-peaked Mossbauer signal.  Pressure drives the YbAlB4 back into a conventional metal, and sure enough, experiments showed that the two peaks fuse into a single peak in the conventional metal. These experiments showed that the strange metal develops very slow charge fluctuations of about a nanosecond (slow for a metal), fluctuations so slow that theory predicted they they would cause the crystal lattice to breath in and out, a prediction confirmed by a careful analysis of the Mossbauer signals.  This crucial discovery has bearing on the ongoing development of theories of the strange metal state, and we hope that parallel experiments can be carried out on other strange metals in the future. 

In parallel with our experimental collaborations, this program of research has also developed new theories of quantum matter.  Part of this work involves the application of new computer algorithms called "Matrix Product states" that we have used to simulate the time-evolution of a new kind of insulator called a Kondo insulator.  In other work, we have been able to study a phenomenon of spin-fractionalization, whereby spins convert to heavy electrons. By carrying out a thought experiment, in which a magnetic flux is inserted into a torus of such material, we were able to demonstrate that the fractionalization of spins into electrons gives rise to a growth in the electron density. (Fig. 4.)
